# Multiple Regression

.box-5[$$Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2 + ... + \beta_p X_p + \varepsilon$$]

Assumptions of the linear regression model:

(i) The conditional mean of $Y$ is **.darkorange[linear]** in the $X_j$ variables

(ii) The error terms are:
  - normally distributed
  - independent from each other
  - identically distributed (i.e. constant variance)

- Last two assumptions are the ones that we refer to when saying $\varepsilon \sim iid$
---
# How can we check these assumptions?

Remember last week's Bechdel test example:

```{r results='hide', message=FALSE,echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
library(firasans)
library(hrbrthemes)
library(extrafont)
library("RColorBrewer")
library(viridis)
library("tm")
library("SnowballC")
library(tidyverse)
library(generics)
library(modelsummary)
library(ggcorrplot)
library(viridis)

rawData <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week1/2_OLS/data/bechdel.csv")

# Select movies pre-1990, and format $-denominated data fields
rawData<-rawData[rawData$Year>1989,]

# Return on Investment (ROI) measures
rawData$ROI<-rawData$Revenue/rawData$Budget #  Total ROI

# Passes Bechdel test:
rawData$pass_bechdel="FAIL"
rawData$pass_bechdel[rawData$rating==3] = "PASS"

# Divide movies into FAIL and PASS divisions
failMovies<-rawData[rawData$binary=="FAIL",]
passMovies<-rawData[rawData$binary=="PASS",]

bechdel = rawData[rawData$Adj_Revenue>0,]

bechdel$imdb = bechdel$imdbRating

bechdel$log_Adj_Revenue = log(bechdel$Adj_Revenue)
bechdel$log_Adj_Budget = log(bechdel$Adj_Budget)
bechdel$bechdel_test=0
bechdel$bechdel_test[bechdel$pass_bechdel=="PASS"] = 1

bechdel_fitted <- augment(lm(log(Adj_Revenue) ~ bechdel_test+log(Adj_Budget) + Metascore + imdbRating, 
                             data = bechdel))
  
```
```{r eval = FALSE}
ggplot(data = bechdel_fitted, aes(x = .std.resid)) + 
  geom_density()

```
```{r bechdel_res, fig.height=4, fig.width=6.5, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}

ggplot(data = bechdel_fitted, aes(x = .std.resid)) + 
  geom_density(color = "#E16462", lwd = 1.3)+
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Std. Residuals") + ylab("Density") +
  #ggplot2::annotate("text", x = 10, y = 6, label = "Adj. R2 = 0.48", size = 6, colour = "dark grey", hjust=0,family="Fira Sans Condensed") +
  theme_bw()+
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain
  xlim(-4,4)+

  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))
```

# What happens if the assumptions break?

.pull-left[
![](https://media.giphy.com/media/fA1OFzprOfRjteYADG/giphy.gif)
]

.pull-right[
- **.darkorange[Don't panic!]** There's still much to be done.

- **.darkorange[Heteroskedasticity]** (non-constant variance) does not bias your estimates.

- Can be fixed many times with **.darkorange[robust standard errors]**
]

# Statistical Adjusment

- Remember that an important part of our job is to **.darkorange[correctly estimate]** the $\beta$ parameters:

  - Point estimates
  - Standard errors
  
- **.darkorange[Two ways]** to estimate standard errors:

  - .darkorange[Direct estimation:] Use probability theory (e.g. $SE(\bar{x}) = \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}$)
  - .darkorange[Simulation:] Repeat the sampling process and estimates how much our estimate changes from one sample to the next (e.g. bootstrapping)

- **.darkorange[Two ways]** to estimate standard errors:

  - .darkorange[Direct estimation:] Use probability theory (e.g. $SE(\bar{x}) = \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}$)
  - .darkorange[Simulation:] Repeat the sampling process and estimates how much our estimate changes from one sample to the next (e.g. bootstrapping)

# Multicollinearity

- If variable `x1` and `x2` are highly correlated, it is difficult to disentangle their effects
  
  - **.darkorange[Context matters!]**
  
---
# Multicollinearity

- If variable `x1` and `x2` are highly correlated, it is difficult to disentangle their effects
  
  - **.darkorange[Context matters!]**
  
- Limit scenario: $|Cor(x_1,x_2)| = 1$

  - Cannot estimate both parameters: One is dropped!

# Does gender matter?

```{r echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
lm_w <- lm(nbeer ~ weight, data = beers)
lm_wh <- lm(nbeer ~ weight + height, data = beers)
lm_wf <- lm(nbeer ~ weight + female, data = beers)
lm_whf <- lm(nbeer ~ weight + height + female, data = beers)

gm <- modelsummary::gof_map

modelsummary(list(lm_w, lm_wh,lm_wf,lm_whf), stars = TRUE, gof_omit = 'DF|AIC|BIC|Log.Lik.|F|Num.Obs.')

```

# Other ways to control for variables

- **.darkorange[Other polynomial terms]**:

  - E,g, The relationship between `weight` and `nbeers` is quadratic.
  
```{r echo=TRUE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
lm(nbeer ~ weight + I(weight^2), data = beers)

```
- How do we interpret these results?
$$\frac{\partial Y_{beers}}{\partial X_w} = \beta_1 + 2\cdot\beta_2 X_w$$

# Other ways to control for variables

- **.darkorange[Categorical variables]**:

  - E,g, You want to include a factor variable for year the student is in.
  
```{r echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}

set.seed(100)
beers$year = sample(c("freshmen","sophmore","junior","senior"),nrow(beers),replace = TRUE)

```
---
# Other ways to control for variables

- **.darkorange[Categorical variables]**:

  - E,g, You want to include a factor variable for year the student is in.
  
```{r echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}

set.seed(100)
beers$year = sample(c("freshmen","sophmore","junior","senior"),nrow(beers),replace = TRUE)

```

```{r echo=TRUE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
table(beers$year)

lm(nbeer ~ weight + factor(year), data = beers)

```
